commentBody:
My five favorite original clues from last week
(in order of appearance):

1. Got on first?  (10)
2. Good for nothing  (7)
3. Big whoop  (4)
4. Exchange letters (3)
5. Chest beating sort  (7)


PREBOARDED
FREEBIE
YELL
IPO
GORILLA
fairly late on Sunday I posted a link to an NYTimes dialect quiz (related to the TAG SALE discussions). If you're so inclined, go check it out. maybe even take the quiz and let us know your results.
I had SUN TsU, and CUs seemed plausible for a few seconds.

ARF. Monday has gone to the dogs.
(Fine with me. Tuesday for cats?)

NARC and KILO in one grid was EERIE.

I was hoping 43A's clue would acknowledge 45A.

Which Grammy year for "It's Raining FRACTALS?"

Thanks, Katie and Jeff. 
SEEYA.

Sam:

I think you mixed your metaphors.  The expression is “a whole other kettle of fish” and not “a whole other can of worms”.  Have I baited some of you out there to dig up evidence to the contrary (along with a few worms)?
Welp, happy to learn a new word on a Monday. Can’t remember when that last happened. Wouldn’t have gotten CHIGNON but for the cross!
This was a little harder for me than my usual encounters with Monday puzzles.
This was a little harder for me than my usual encounters with Monday puzzles.

This was a tidy little Monday puzzle.  For some reason it tickled me more than the typical Monday.  I was amused to see PARTNERTRACK as an answer having ridden those rails myself once upon a time.  I also liked ULTA and ALTA in the same puzzle, despite never having heard of ULTA before.
Anglicism was my undoing. Briticism? I suppose it must be correct.
I’m a Mon / Tue gal and this was beyond my skill set. Now if you’ll excuse me I’ll be practicing a chignon.

What the.  No way was that normal Monday difficulty.

Is it because of the holiday that the NYT allowed this to be published?  It wasn't "hard" per se but it was certainly much "chewier" and with more esoterica than anything I've seen here before.

Honestly it just seems like a mistake.  It would have been fine for a Wednesday or even a Friday in my estimation.

Maybe we shouldn't complain - challenging well made puzzles are fun.  But this isn't fair to people who have come to rely on the escalating pattern over the week (not to mention those who for some reason care about completion time stats).

____________________
Jesse Goldberg 8/28/2024 for Puzzle of the Decade
(emu filler)

Well, well - bruh makes another appearance, but this time as a clue.  All is forgiven with the appearance of chignon - how very French and how very elegant.

I think Monday will be a day to raid the archives as I try to hold on to some positive thinking.

Happy solving.
That was a chewy crossword for a Monday. Much slower than my average times. CHIGNONS only happened because of the cross and CRYSTALS instead of FRACTALS made ne lose a lot of time.

I WORKed LIKE A DOG to fill in this grid and already in the NW thought I'd be defeated by a Monday. I had to jump all over the puzzle to make it come together.

Were it not for the crosses, I wouldn't have remembered FRACTALS.
Also, I've always heard it as BRITIshISM, so that threw me off.
Luckily, CHIGNONS are my UPDOs of choice and the ULTA store is right up my alley.

FOLLOW THE HERDS reminded me of my observation of how we humans tend to subconsciously move in herds. 
That's why the lines at a supermarket will be suddenly long. But if you step away for something between five and ten minutes, upon your return all the lines will be gone. 

Back to the puzzle, I found it intense but ultimately enjoyable as it all came together and assuaged my initial fears that I'm regressing in puzzle-solving abilities.

Thank you, Katie and Jeff, for this more challenging Monday puzzle!

I'm still editing this paper about dogs - it's just my ruff draft.

(Don't worry, I won't furget about it.)

Hi all! Puzzle of the Year voting time! This is the first round of voting for the POY for 2024. Nominees are in four groups: Early Week (Monday–Wednesday), Thursday, Themeless (Friday & Saturday) and Sunday. As in years past, there will be two rounds of voting. In the first round, you may select up to FIVE puzzles in each group. The five puzzles receiving the most votes will move on to the second round of voting. First round voting ends January 24. Here's the link to the ballot: https://form.jotform.com/243358842724059 The ballots are really easy to use. At the bottom of the first three pages you'll see NEXT: click that to go to the next category. Anyone can vote, but please only submit one set of ballots per person (i.e., don't stuff the ballot box).

A bit harder than a typical Monday, but within the typical range of difficulty. I got held up with FOLLOWTHELEAD. Had to check the crosses at the end, as all the across entries were filled, and I skip filled entries on the app. 

And then I was sure, at first pass that it was UKENGLISH, and then was sure it was BRITIDIOM.
Relatively easy, but not very fun.

That one cracked along, despite several unknowns that had to be filled on the cross and/or guessed. The crosses between two unknown proper nouns down, O_EARY and S_ACIE, and one unknown proper noun across (clued by another unknown proper noun), U__A, was filled on balance of pretty reasonable probabilities. 
Then I didn't get my star! Careful scanning revealed a new error for me: UPD0 (with a zero!) instead of UPDO.

Was momentarily vexed because LLAMAS come in herds or flocks, not packs. 
And then, doh, the delayed realization that they're described as pack animals because they carry stuff. Sometimes even packs.

Yeah this was quite a lot harder than recent Mondays. Chignon/Herd was where I got stuck. I had LEAD and was pretty sure AOIL wasn't a thing but there were one to many variables in that section for me today. Cheers
This was a really clever Monday theme. Four career paths for a dog! Who knew? Thanks, Katie Byl and Jeff Chen.
Surely CUS/SUNTSU is an acceptable spelling for both crossings?

CUZ?

Can someone please explain for this Australian?
CUZ means your cousin here.

So, I'm supposed to know a Sephora rival and Kevin of Shark Tank?  On a Monday?  I don't even really know either Sephora or Shark Tank!

I'm not doing anymore Jeff Chen puzzles.
BRITICISM, ironically, is an Americanism. We tend to say Britishism.
I suppose this is as good a time as any to make this observation: In all my many and ever increasing years working in veterinary medicine, not once have I ever met a dog named FIDO.
Fun puzzle! A tough one for a Monday which is nice :)

Bit difficult for a Monday, but I’m not against that. 

My main criticism is it just wasn’t fun. 

A couple of pretty obscure clues in here. CUZ is probably my most hated lol. Also happy to be corrected here, but I really dislike seeing NEWB/S keep turning up in these puzzles. For anyone online who actually uses the term, it’s spelled NOOB/S.

OLEARY and ULTA … bleh 

Can we please have puzzles and not quizzes 

Thanks

Herds don’t have wisdom. They follow leads.

Two names and a brand crossing, on a Monday - and a brand like ULTA, which seems like somebody put together some letters at random... Is the constructor from Natick? 🤣

This was a slog for me in general: not the relaxing, easy Monday puzzle I was looking forward to. It took as long as a typical Tuesday, and I needed lookups for the natick...
Quite difficult and not fun whatsoever.
Easy and fun one for me. Thanks for a great puzzle!

Strands thread.  Please reserve any spoilers for after the View All Replies button: 


Strands #323
“Curiouser and curiouser!”
🟡🔵🔵🔵
🔵🔵

A smooth Sam Corbin Monday.

Huh. It’s always interesting to discover how others rate the puzzle in terms of difficulty. Although many found this one tough for a Monday, for me it was below my average Monday time— and might even have been a PB had it not been for an unusual number of fat finger flubs. When I looked it over, though, I would have expected a Monday to be kinder to the international solvers; seemed like quite a few U.S.-centric entries, which I would have thought would be minimized on a Monday. 

I think the perception of difficulty might also have been influenced by the fact that this puzzle may have favored female solvers. There were two questions on hairstyles (that referred to mostly feminine styles) and one on makeup, as well as a question about a doll. Absolutely NOT saying males don’t/shouldn’t play with dolls or wear makeup— or be familiar with women’s hairstyles (if there is such a distinction!)— just that fewer men are likely to find these topics in their wheelhouse.

Relieved to see I'm not alone in finding this one an unusually tough Monday. Quite a workout for me, but managed to get it all together. Will confess that I wasn't really tumbling to the trick until I was almost done and went back and reviewed. Fun puzzle find today - a Wednesday from November 15, 2017 by Steven E. Atwood. The reveal clue and answer in that one: "Words found in the answers to this puzzle's starred clues" BRITISHISMS And some theme clue and answer examples: "*Monthly charge for a London apartment?" FLATRATE "*French fries on a London card table?" POKERCHIPS "*Part of a London police officer's uniform?" BOBBYSOCKS "*Conveyance in a multilevel London store?" SHOPLIFT Thought that was pretty clever. Here's the Xword Info link: https://xwordinfo.com/Crossword?date=11/15/2017&g=11&d=D I'm done. ...

I agree with the comments that this was unexpectedly difficult for a Monday. 

ARF - why would this be [High-pitched]? I would think yip or yap would be high pitched, but not ARF. The F on the end of ARF and woof has always suggested to me the sound of expelled air, and that suggests to me the larger lungs of a bigger dog with a lower-pitched bark. 

Clearly my love of dogs is causing me to overthink this LOL But it struck me as odd.
Wonderful debut and great theme, Katie.  Nice way to get the pronunciation of your last name out there.  I definitely said it wrong in my head when I first saw it.
Thought for the day: https://gocomics.com/mattwuerker/2025/01/17 Now we have to move on to 3.0. Persist. Resist. Organize.

One thing I can say about this community of  commenters is that they drive me to look into things about which I might otherwise never have thought.  For example, comments about 36A.  (As an aside, I must say firstly that while I have heard of a “herd mentality”, I have never heard of this particular expression.)  But on to my point.  I think, but am not certain, that someone commented, in the context of this clue, on lemmings.  That drove me to explore the web to see if there is known, if not well-known, term for a group of lemmings, which led me to this:

The myth that lemmings plunge  over a cliff -- or that they commit
mass suicide in other ways, like drowning -- is apparently just that, a myth.
It was created (one hears) by Walt Disney's brother, who thought it made a
cool visual effect. That this is all a myth is apparently well known to
biologists (any out there?), but not to the common person (indeed, my Webster's
Collegiate makes reference to it).
Therefore, I propose "a slander of lemmings."
“Briticism” but uses examples that are both also used in Australia

I got through most of it without too many problems, but the SW corner had me hostage for about 15 minutes. Never heard of BRITICISM, despite being a Brit, I was hindered by having angl-ICISM in my mind. Quite a few tricky Americanisms in other parts of the puzzle, but it's the NYT so whaddyagonnadoo?
The dog theme was cute. Thanks Katie & Jeff, I always appreciate the effort constructors put in, and the brain workout!
Monday should mean not having to look anything up.

Congratulations Professor Byl on your NYT debut.  A smooth solve with my only stumble plugging in righTGUARD* for the B-ballers.  Good canine fun and thanks.  

*Probably from long suppressed adolescent memory of lighting the spray deodorant with a lighter to produce a flame thrower effect.

I agree with a lot of the comments that there were a few rough clues in this one. I got lucky with picking the "right" spelling of Sun Tzu and somehow pulled Kevin O'Leary's name from the back of my mind despite having no idea where I'd heard it.

But despite these I overall still found it enjoyable. Would have been a solid Tuesday puzzle.

One of the few places I expect to find proper usage is here.  I guess that should now be "was here."  "Since" relates to time, not causation.  "Follow the herd"?  In what universe?  And "Briticism"?  The only people that apparently use that term are the constructors.  While it may be technically correct (someone else mentioned its appearance in a dictionary), I have never once in a very long life heard or read it.  Just a dismal exercise.

I think my dog is part fractal:
every bit of him smells as bad as the whole thing.

If this puzzle could speak, it might say “I work like a Tuesday.”
Jeff Chen?  On a Monday???????

A word about Naticks, for those who complained about ULTA/O'LEARY and for Natick complainers in general.

The original "Natick" was NATICK and N.C. WYETH crossing at 1A. The N was the artist's first initial, and as such, completely uninferrable in any way, while in the other direction, it could have been practically any letter.  And not knowing either one would lead to being totally stuck.  Being at 1A, there was less surrounding context to help out than usual.

Having traveled the Mass Pike a few times in my life, I knew NATICK.  But I didn't know N.C. WYETH's first initial.

If you don't live near one (practically impossible around here, though), I'd forgive you for not knowing ULTA.  (I did; there's one less than five miles from here.)  And I'd also forgive you for not knowing who stars in Shark Tank.  (I didn't.)

But at the cross, you're left with the letter missing in U_TA and O_EARY.  

Overseas solvers, you're excused if you didn't see O'LEARY immediately, but it's a really common name here.  But the rest of you should have, really.

I grant you that it's not as obvious what goes in the other direction, but the L looks good because it reminds one of "ultimate."

I submit that the real reason people got upset about this crossing is that they didn't have most of the surrounding words, most of which seemed pretty easy to me.  Sounded like a cat?  A girl's name?  Assigned a job?  Blog POST?  

Come on, folks.  It's EERIE how many people resort to calling "Natick"!

I wasn’t able to guess the revealer today, maybe because my dog Teddy doesn’t specialize in tracking, guarding, herding, or guiding.  He does specialize in being a heartmelter and smileprompter, however.  These qualities make him more than simply OF USE; they mark him as a stroke of fortune in my life.

Dogs are relatively recent in my life – I’ve had three now in the past decade – and yes, I am enamored of and grateful for them.  Life brighteners.  Treasured gifts.

So, Katie and Jeff, your dog puzzle set my day right.  The theme, yes, but also its echoes: 
•	The cross of ARF and FIDO.
•	The adjacent Boggle-style DOGs in the upper middle, one being part of a Boggle-style UPDOG.  
•	The fact that this has struck some as “Chewy” for a Monday puzzle.

Plus, little bonuses like EDGE abutting the border, a semordnilap pair in the grid (NIL, LIN), and the gorgeous symmetrical pair of FRACTALS and CHIGNONS.  

Congratulations to you, Katie, on your first Times puzzle, and thank you, Jeff, for partnering so often with new constructors; you help keep Crosslandia vibrant.

Thank you both for bringing a heap of happy my way today!

I enjoyed the unexpected extra toughness of this one - this is a challenging Monday anyway, and I appreciate having my brain otherwise occupied. I didn’t get the theme until I read the column, but that didn’t hurt my solving. Came in about 2 minutes longer than my average Monday time.

Lovely, chill Monday.

BILLs won, 
so my head is *cloudy*
which is actually pronounced

*hung over*

and I needed a smooth and creamy solve.

Thank you Katie and Jeff!
The only brief hiccup (hiccough more common from 1849-1949) was thinking FOLLOWTHE LEAD but quickly realized that wouldn't work with ROIL.  Otherwise, this was very easy

Fun Monday puzzle. Good to keep one's mind off bad things happening today.

I don't want to brag,, but yesterday I got the lipstick company without any crosses. Other people might not think it's obscure, but the only place I've ever heard of it is here.

All honor to Martin Luther King today. The work is not done.

With FRACTALS, CHIGNONS and SUNTZU, this one seemed Tuesday-ish to me. My solve-time agreed, exceeding my Tuesday average by half-a-minute.

ALTA and ULTA appearing together was interesting. NOGOAREAS sounds odd to me; needless to say my initial entry was NOGOZONES.

Having PURRED in the grid was clever, though it should have been clued as "Worked like a cat". ;-)

My first fractal was creating Lsystems in 1989 during my master's; on a monitor with 16 colours, using Turbo Pascal! Took about 20 minutes to generate a tree. Now I do this with Arduino Uno and miniature 240 x 240 displays. Now off to solving...

Another toughish Monday, welcome back Mr Shortz.
Like the dog theme; my Shiba doesn’t so much ARF as scream until your ears bleed at any and all perceived ‘attacks’ on property or person. A good guard dog who takes no prisoners. If you ever see a photo of them with that cute foxy face and permanent smile, don’t be fooled. They’re Cane Corsas in disguise.

The unknown names caused a few sticky moments, but the crosses helped eventually.

BRITICISM a new one in me. I was trying to cram the more familiar Britishism in.

Given my mini rant re maths themes yesterday I was both surprised and pleased with myself to get FRACTALS without needing all the crosses. Look at me, learning numbers and stuff. Stick that in your pipe ye legion of hideous 1960’s maths teachers. Mind, I couldn’t have told you what a FRACTAL actually is, but still, progress.
Chignon, cool!

This was rather challenging for a Monday, but I managed to get through it with no lookups. (Even 11D  and 16A were eventually revealed by the crossing words.) As a cat person, I appreciated 9D. Totally forgot about the theme until reading Gameplay. This is the first time I can remember seeing 12D as a verb. However, FRACTALS were familiar. 61A was, unfortunately, not "Britspeak".

Not quite as much easy fun as the usual Monday puzzle, but OK.

The puzzle seems perfectly Monday easy to me. Filled smoothly, no hangups, zero write-overs.
I worked the puzzle last night after it dropped, so perhaps the lack of Monday morning mind malaise made it easier.

I liked it, DOGgone it!
Thank you, Katie and Jeff.

My NO-GO AREAS today are politics and farcebook. Rather like Whamadeddon, a challenge to avoid them.

OK, OK, I'm awake now! Good workout for a Monday morning! 
We got 1/2" of icy snow over ice. Was out scraping the walk and putting down salt earlier. 
Stay warm, everyone!

I worry that the cutesy BRITICISM just encourages Brits to keep using the wrong words for things.

I used to find it endearing, but I'm tyred of it.




It's been a hard day's night, and I've been ...

Well, I prefer BRITISHISM to BRiTICISM, but of course it's hard to walk away from a witticism, ism it?  CUZ they're so fun.

Difficult to know if it's NOOB or NEWB, and apparently I don't know the correct order for LBGT, either.  TSK TSK indeed.

Clever and interesting theme!  Having recently read James Rebanks's three books (he is a shepherd with HERDing DOGs)--I was primed for acton here.  In fact, as I look back:  An early Scholastic Book was _Follow My Leader_ about a boy who gets a GUIDE DOG after losing his eye-sight.  And did anyone else read all the DOG books by Albert Terhune?  Not to mention Jack London's _Call of the Wild_ and goodness!  Gipson's _Old Yeller_.
Is this an unusual background for a Cat Person?

Bright sunshine today, allowing the cold to move in without the protection of clouds... and I do believe that h*ll did freeze over!

For those who found it a breezy Monday,...

For those who found it a difficult Monday,...

There is a phrase:

YMMV
"Your mileage may vary."
I just have to comment that I loved the Ira Glass clue. This puzzle challenged me a bit for a Monday, but it was a lot of fun. Nice work Professor Byl.

So today we have Master Sun transliterated as SUNTZU, but the Old Master is always LAOTSE. What's up with that? Can somebody check the STYLE GUIDE for me? I'm sure it only annoys me because I speak Mandarin. (Chinese dogs say "wang-wang.")

A few years ago, my sister adopted a failed guide dog. If you met her you would understand. Her name is Loopy. I'll just leave it at that.

I recommend checking out Professor Byl's comments on Xwordinfo, which are different that her comments here. I do wish they'd kept her clue for 1A ["I'm just a ___" ("Schoolhouse Rock!" song)]. Way more fun than [Unwanted piece of mail]!

WOW! 

*checks calendar*

Stickiest Monday in quite some time! I thoroughly enjoyed this very well-crafted puzzle.
Monday puzzles can occasionally be a little ho-hum, but this one was a delight to solve. Thanks Katie and Jeff 😊👏🏻

Troublingly tricky for a Monday! It felt like a lot of clues just weren't getting through to my brain. "Bad you!" ??? Given the theme I thought it was supposed to be like something you'd say to a dog to get them to stop eating your homework. My total lack of fluency in legalese also didn't help. I also have to, like everyone else, complain about BRITICISM. But some positivity - I loved SEEYA crossed with BYE in the bottom right corner, which my left-to-right and top-to-bottom brain always parses as the "end" of the puzzle. Cute!

I wish there was a  puzzle this much fun for dogs. I have two blueticks, it is 7 degrees outside, and my dogs are bored. They live to smell things, so while we walk a lot, it is often slowly because they are busy reading the news.
A new low. At least three lookups needed to finish a MONday!

This was hard for a Monday, but I loved it anyway!

The crossing of ARF and FIDO was super-cute, given the theme. I also liked BYE and SEE YA at the end of the puzzle. LLAMAS, FRACTALS, CHIGNONS, this puzzle had a lot of fun fill.

While normally I love word play,
having (very) recently heard someone misuse an oath,
right now the idea of taking words lightly
seems distasteful to me.

Somehow today, remember truth is about reality,
so surely it’s got to return before too long.

Yeesh. All the complaints. This was just a bit under my Monday average for solve time. I thought it was definitely a Monday puzzle and quite a good one too!  Really enjoyed the revealer and the tie ins to working dogs. Clever. Thanks!

I was pretty annoyed by 25A's "since" being related to "cuz" (because). But this helped me accept the clue: https://dictionary.cambridge.org/grammar/british-grammar/as-because-or-since Also didn't know briticism could be done with a "c" and i get it, but not sure i approve =)
boo

I stared at OF USE for way too long wondering what the word "OFUSE" meant.
A good mix of easy Monday fill and a snag or two to keep your head in the game!
Happy victory Monday, Bills fans!

Wow! I actually completed it in less than an hour. Yes, I’m not nearly as good as the majority of NY Times Crossworders. I definitely feel smart and confident about myself today lol! Best of luck to everyone especially now. One day at a time just like one puzzle at a time! Namaste!!
I agree with your perspective.   The clue was valid, but the high pitch aspect made it more of misdirect appropriate for a Thu-Sun crossword than for the cluing on a Monday.

I solved the puzzle during my lunch break on my (Android) phone, but waited until I got home to fill in the revealer and get the happy music--on my PC. ON BOTH PLATFORMS, five letters in the NW were in pale gray rather than black:

13A:     I  E
17A:     T A
                P

Does this mean something, or is it just a glitch? If the latter, odd it would be in both places.

Lots to love here from Katie and Jeff, and ... FIDO.

In keeping with the theme, POINT and FOLLOW are also jobs for which canines might be TASKED. And if we're thinking of dogs as faithful companions and fashion accessories, why not PARTNER and STYLE? ARF!

Examples of NO GO AREAS when potty training a puppy include the RUG. Please use the dog DOOR.

Finally, for cat lovers out there, Katie and Jeff have tossed a bone -- PURRED.

SEEYA. BYE. I'M OUT.

No matter how close or far one looks at these comments, all one sees is whining. 
Therefore, the NYT XWord comments page is a FRACTAL.

My app has frozen even though the puzzle is complete. I have rebooted my phone and also did a force stop on the app.

I can't delete or type in any letters and all menu items are grey!!! The time Conner keeps going, it's the only part working. I'm going to lose my streak due to this bug.

Any advice?
Great puzzle collaboration, Katie and Jeff....but it's not a Monday challenge....scares off newbs. That's on Will, not y'all. Hope to see more from you two again!

Careful - there are a lot of Narcs around here…


And an emu!
Cuz when? Nope. I enjoyed today's puzzle, but cuz I enjoy them all, that's redundant. Nope, just nope. Clue maker must be a nOOb.
This is not a typical Monday puzzle much too difficult!
I thought it was just me, that maybe I wasn't so sharp today. Then I saw I'm not the only one finding this difficult for a Monday. Win some, lose some.
Omg!!! I thought I was gonna break my streak on a Monday I was stressing!!! Finally found my error, NEWBS - SAP not NEWBZ - ZAP

Unfamiliar with CHIGNONS so I had “follow the lead” instead of FOLLOW THE HERD, and it had me stuck for awhile but I eventually worked through it. I thought it fit the theme since lead dogs are a thing in dog sledding. Also had “junk” and “spam” in mind instead of BILL which totally slowed me down up in the northwest for awhile too. Love dogs, loved the theme, good that this Monday was a bit more challenging! Thank you!
Just to be a little pedantic (because today is THE day and I’m moody), but a high-pitched bark is a YIP or YAP. Otherwise just say a bark, there’s no need to elaborate further.
Ah, love the theme.   "track, herd, guide, guard"   Canine tasks.  Love it!  arf, bye.
Got it in 28 minutes _with no look-ups_!    I know for most solvers here, on a Monday, that's nothing to brag about.   But for me, no cheating/ zero look-ups is exciting.

@Lewis 

Unless you’re a baseball fan, you don’t notice any wordplay with [Got on first?].  To our European contingent, this probably reads like a straight clue.

@Lewis 

Chest-beating sort wasn't much of a misdirect, IMO.

@Steve L 

Yeah. I had no idea wordplay was involved.

@Steve L 
After watching the clip of "Who's on first" I will try to remember that "on first" has more than one meaning.

@Bob T. 

Too funny, it had me all over the place and has me scratching my head...
Newark
Pembroke, FL
Honolulu

I grew up in New York, go to Miami yearly to visit family, and have never been to Honolulu.

And I guess I've managed to live in Washington D.C., Austin TX, and Portland OR without picking up the regionalisms.

@sotto voce 
If you only subscribed to games, you can't read the article (or take the quiz).
Grumpy, See if this lets you in: https://nytimes.com/interactive/2014/upshot/dialect-quiz-map.html?unlocked_article_code=1.qk4.Axos.x9rsEavBrfO2&smid=url-share

@Barry Ancona 
Yes, that worked. Thanks.

Grumpy, 

You're welcome. Hope you enjoyed it.

I remember trying it when it was first published. My "real" voice is New York, but I was also able to produce a spot-on "Iowa" and some passable other regions.

@Bob T. It pegs me as Chicago  / Aurora IL /Minneapolis. I was born in Chicago and so were both my parents, and one of my daughters. And the other daughter.... went to high school in Aurora and lives in Minneapolis. Cold pop and new gym shoes for you guys!

@Bob T. 

New York all the way though I haven't lived in the city since I was 18.

Does it matter that my mother was a school teacher?

Quiz didn't ask about gum bands or Mt Worshington.

@Barry Ancona 

Thanks, that link worked for me. It nailed me (quite accurately) as very Midwestern.

@Al  in Pittsburgh 
With difficulty, I managed to replace worsh with wash several years ago.

Thanks for the working link for non-subscribers, Barry! You're awesome ❤️

That was a very interesting quiz. Apparently I have a Maine accent 🤪. Can one pick up an accent by reading Stephen King novels? 🤣

@Barry Ancona 
Thank you! 
This is fascinating for anyone interested in words. I don't think you really pick up on these differences on US television. 
On Law and OrderI noticed there are quite a lot of Yiddish words used by some characters.

I tried it myself for fun - my (Scots) accent is most similar to those right on the west coast. Some I had no answer for eg I call a soft drink 'juice' (as opposed to 'fruit juice' and a major road is a 'motorway'. In Glasgow soft drinks were always 'ginger' but it might have changed.
I have no word for an easy College course, I don't really think anyone does; though maths and physics are reckoned to be the hardest.
I think there are fewer courses in the UK. 
Thanks again for the link.

@Bob T. 

Fun!

I took the quiz and was given 3 locales: Providence (RI), Springfield and Worcester (both in MA).

I was born in Providence, lived in Springfield from 1st to 7th grade, then back to Providence for the rest of my schooling.  So I guess a mixture of the lingo is built in! (I don't drop my Rs in speech like other RI-ers including my Mother - that's probably the Western MA influence)

I have no connection to Worcester other than it's in between those other two cities.

Very interesting!

Thanks for the link!
The top 3 cities for my dialect were all in south Florida.... I don't think you could get farther away from me in the US! 😆

(emu filler)
@Dave Briticism is apparently the American version of Britishism and predates the latter by about twenty years. Who knew?
@Dave “Since” can also be used for “because” - “Since it was a Monday, I expected an easier puzzle.”
I wasn’t going to say anything but, since you brought it up, I thought I’d just mention that “since” is often used for causation and not just time.
@Amy Merely because some people use "since" for "because" doesn't make it any more correct than those who have turned "impact" into a verb.  Popular usage ain't the same thing as proper usage.

@Dave @Dave 
Since you in your “very long life” have never heard a term, or learned a particular dictionary-approved usage, then those words/expressions/usages should be forbidden in the crossword? Interesting concept… when were you anointed arbiter of acceptability? CUZ  somehow I missed the memo.

Dave,

Since you brought it up, 
it’s been about 38 minutes.

@Dave I use BRITICISM (and Scotticism and Anglicìsm and Gallicism). So I was slightly surprised to see how much trouble it caused, and also to discover that the OED calls it "Orig. U.S." FOLLOW THE HERD was also very familiar to me, and I've used it on occasion. As for "since" used to indicate causation, I once wrote an entire blog post about that, with examples: https://oikofuge.com/sith/ Seems like this one was just right in my wheelhouse, and unfortunately not in yours. But sometimes unfamiliar usages turn out to be commonplace to others.

And how long does a usage need to be "popular" before it becomes "correct"? Because "since" has been implying causation for at least 300 years, since we stopped using the word "sith" in that context.

This has the feeling of one of those usage "rules" invented by nineteenth century grammarians, in the teeth of the evidence.

@Dave I'm in agreement with you regarding "since".  However, most people are unaware of the since/because distinction.  I work at a university and have found this error in documents written by professors and high-ranking administrators.  I was asked to proofread a document for one such person, and when I made that correction, she admitted that she wasn't aware of the distinction.

I just waded through a succession of style and usage manuals looking for any mention of the putative since / because distinction. Even the Fowler brothers didn't seem to think it was worth a mention. 
Eventually I turned this up in Garner's "Modern American Usage".
"since. This subordinate conjunction may bear a sense either of time or logical connection. Despite the canard that the word properly relates only to time, the causal meaning has existed continuously in the English language for more than a thousand years." (I assume he's treating Old English "sithence" as being continuous with "since".)

For those unfamiliar with the word "canard", the OED defines it thus: "An extravagant or absurd story circulated to impose on people's credulity; a hoax, a false report."

@Dave According to M-W, when "since" is used as a conjunction, it can mean "in view of the fact that : because." The example usage they provide: "since it was raining she took an umbrella" https://merriam-webster.com/dictionary/since This makes sense to me because causation also relates to time (unlike correlation).

@HeathieJ 

So beautifully stated!
I think you captured it perfectly, from Steve L's maybe-somewhat-irritation to his willingness to thoroughly explain and teach.

And I'm 100% with you on this because I've also learned so much from him, as well as from Barry and Eric H. 

The info they contribute are worth their way in gold to those who would keep an open mind to the teachings.

@Mr Dave 

I think you missed my point, which was not to complain, but rather to explain to people that they should take the time to reason it out.  The editors do a very good job making sure difficult words are fairly crossed.

I reached my current level of successfully solving the puzzle "when, not if", by realizing that the puzzles are structured to be solved by people with reasonable knowledge bases. 

Which brings me to the thing I say over and over again, that if you don't read the rest of the paper, you can expect to be good at the puzzle.  Now I realize that that not everyone who solves has a subscription to the rest of the paper (I started saying that back when they had to) but you have to keep up with all kinds of current events, including pop culture, some way or other.  People who keep complaining about these things being in the puzzle are unrealistic in their wishes; the puzzle was designed for people who are aware of the culture around them.

@HeathieJ 

Thanks for your support and appreciation.  The other day, someone replied scathingly about something similar I said, and it annoyed me.  The problem is that a lot of people who stop by to complain don't read--or if they do, don't absorb or buy into--my suggestions.  Or they take them the wrong way.

I currently have something like a nine-year streak (without lookups, I might add), which might have even been longer if I had gotten on the NYT app when it first came out (I was using a very good platform, Pizzazz, now defunct, at the time).  If people don't want to listen to what I have to say, so be it.  

I'm not the mean girl from middle school.

@Steve L 

Plenty of us know you aren't but it must be so frustrating to get the negative responses you do. I'm grateful you keep at it despite the naysayers. 

I'm a better solver because of you, and I hope to one day reach the place you are in of knowing you absolutely can solve the puzzle without help. I'm definitely not there but I'm much further along, in no small part, because of you and other high-level solvers who generously share their expertise. 

Cheers to you!!  :-)

@Nancy J. 

I'm late to this thread, but wanted to chime in. 

"people see a name they don't know and just assume it is uninferrable" 

This rings very true, I believe. I picture it as a sort of deer-in-the-headlights moment, where the solver freezes instead of being patient and working the crosses. 

A good example was the [_____ Borg] clue the other day, where the fairly gentle crosses served up _NIT_. There were a number of comments decrying the "Natick", but staying calm and considering women's names goes a long way: you don't have to *know* the answer of who the person was in order to *solve* it. 

That said, recently there was a real stumper, top row where the down was an initialed sportsman and the across I didn't know. I ended up running the alphabet... It happens sometimes, and it is what it is. Did I adore that puzzle? No. Is that a big deal? Nope! 

As always, great advice from you. Thanks!

It doesn't seem to do anything apart from print letters in grey when activated, which does transfer betweeen devices along with the rest of your solve progress.
I use it to remind me of guesses. For instance, today, my 16A has the letters L and T in grey. So if I don't get a gold star and a happy tune at the end of the fill, the "grey areas" are the first to revisit.
Not that it helped today, because my problem was a zero instead of an O in UPDO!
